scope.gco:CharacterString: Codelists for description of metadata datasets compliant with SeaDataNet 19115:2003 and 19139 profiles

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Added in ISO 3166-1 Newsletter VI-8 (2010-12-15)). Code was formerly used for the British Antarctic Territory
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Bonaire, Sint Eustatius and Saba

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Merged to form part of Antarctica AQ in 1979
CodeDefinition.gml:name: British Antarctic Territory

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Changed its name to Myanmar MM in 1989. BU is reserved for reuse.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Burma

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Merged to form part of Kiribati KI in 1984.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Canton and Enderbury Islands
Congo, The Democratic Republic of the

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Added in ISO 3166-1 Newsletter VI-8 (2010-12-15)).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Curaçao

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Split up into Czech Republic CZ and Slovakia SK in 1993. CS was reassigned to Serbia and Montenegro until its split in 2006.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Czechoslovakia

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Changed its name to Benin BJ in 1977.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Dahomey

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Merged to form part of Viet Nam VN in 1977.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Democratic Republic of Viet-Nam

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Merged to form part of Yemen YE in 1990.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Democratic Yemen

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Merged to form part of Antarctica AQ in 1983
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Dronning Maud Land

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Changed its code to TL in 2002. TP reserved for reuse.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: East Timor

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Split up into Adélie Land, which merged to form part of Antarctica AQ, and French Southern Territories TF in 1979.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: French Southern and Antarctic Territories

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Changed its name to Djibouti DJ in 1977. AI has been reassigned to Anguilla.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: French Territory of the Afars and the Issas

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Merged to form part of Germany DE in 1990.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: German Democratic Republic

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Split up into Kiribati KI and Tuvalu TV in 1979. GE has been reassigned to Georgia.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Gilbert and Ellice Islands

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Merged to form part of United States Minor Outlying Islands UM in 1986.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Johnston Island
Macedonia, The Former Yugoslav Republic of

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Merged to form part of France FR in 1997.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Metropolitan France

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Merged to form part of United States Minor Outlying Islands UM in 1986.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Midway Islands

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Split into Bonaire, Sint Eustatius and Saba BQ and Curaçao CW (ISO 3166-1 Newsletter VI-8 (2010-12-15))
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Netherlands Antilles

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Split up into two parts, which merged to form parts of Iraq IQ and Saudi Arabia SA respectively in 1993. NT reserved for reuse.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Neutral Zone

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Changed its name to Vanuatu VU in 1980.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: New Hebrides

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Merged to form part of Panama PA in 1980.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Panama Canal Zone

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Changed its name to Zimbabwe ZW in 1980.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Rhodesia

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Added in ISO Newsletter published 2007-09-21
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Saint Barthélemy
Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Added in ISO Newsletter published 2007-09-21
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Saint Martin (French part)

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Split up into Montenegro ME and Serbia RS in 2006. Code CS reserved for potential reuse.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Serbia and Montenegro

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Merged to form part of India IN in 1975. SK has been reassigned to Slovakia.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Sikkim

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Added in ISO 3166-1 Newsletter VI-8 (2010-12-15)).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Sint Maarten (Dutch part)
South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Added in ISO Newsletter published 2011-08-16
CodeDefinition.gml:name: South Sudan

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Split up into Federated States of Micronesia FM, Marshall Islands MH, Northern Mariana Islands MP, and Palau PW in 1986.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Consisting of Baker Island, Howland Island, Jarvis Island, Kingman Reef, and Palmyra Atoll. Merged to form part of United States Minor Outlying Islands UM in 1986.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: U.S. Miscellaneous Pacific Islands

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Split up in 1992. Code SU is reserved for reuse.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: U.S.S.R.

CodeDefinition.gml:description: The correct value is not known to, and not computable by, the sender of this data. However, a correct value probably exists
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Unknown

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Changed its name to Burkina Faso BF in 1984.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Upper Volta

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Merged to form part of United States Minor Outlying Islands UM in 1986.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Wake Island

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Represented Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia until 1991 and Federal Republic of Yugoslavia from 1992 to 2003. Changed its name to Serbia and Montenegro CS. YU reserved for reuse.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Yugoslavia

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Changed its name to Democratic Republic of the Congo CD in 1997. ZR reserved for reuse.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Zaire

CodeDefinition.gml:description: There is no appropriate value
CodeDefinition.gml:name: inapplicable

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An energy source with a frequency up to 1000 Hz (sampling interval ranging from 2-0.5 msec) plus a multiple strings of towed hydrophones (streamers) that determine geologic structure by detecting waves reflected by subsurface layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: 1000 Hz top-bandwidth multi-channel seismic reflection systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An energy source with a frequency up to 1000 Hz (sampling interval ranging from 2-0.5 msec) plus a single string of towed hydrophones (streamer) that determine geologic structure by detecting waves reflected by subsurface layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: 1000 Hz top-bandwidth single-channel seismic reflection systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An energy source with a frequency up to 2000 Hz (sampling interval ranging from 0.5-0.25 msec) plus a multiple strings of towed hydrophones (streamers) that determine geologic structure by detecting waves reflected by subsurface layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: 2000 Hz top-bandwidth multi-channel seismic reflection systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An energy source with a frequency up to 2000 Hz (sampling interval ranging from 0.5-0.25 msec) plus a single string of towed hydrophones (streamer) that determine geologic structure by detecting waves reflected by subsurface layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: 2000 Hz top-bandwidth single-channel seismic reflection systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An energy source with a frequency up to 250 Hz (sampling interval ranging from 2-8 msec) plus a multiple strings of towed hydrophones (streamers) that determine geologic structure by detecting waves reflected by subsurface layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: 250 Hz top-bandwidth multi-channel seismic reflection systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An energy source with a frequency up to 250 Hz (sampling interval ranging from 2-8 msec) plus a single string of towed hydrophones (streamer) that determine geologic structure by detecting waves reflected by subsurface layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: 250 Hz top-bandwidth single-channel seismic reflection systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An energy source with a frequency up to 60 Hz (sampling interval higher than 8 msec) plus a multiple strings of towed hydrophones (streamers) that determine geologic structure by detecting waves reflected by subsurface layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: 60 Hz top-bandwidth multi-channel seismic reflection systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An energy source with a frequency up to 60 Hz (sampling interval higher than 8 msec) plus a single string of towed hydrophones (streamer) that determine geologic structure by detecting waves reflected by subsurface layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: 60 Hz top-bandwidth single-channel seismic reflection systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An energy source with a frequency up to >2000 Hz (sampling interval lower than 0.25 msec) plus a multiple strings of towed hydrophones (streamers) that determine geologic structure by detecting waves reflected by subsurface layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: >2000 Hz top-bandwidth multi-channel seismic reflection systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An energy source with a frequency up to >2000 Hz (sampling interval lower than 0.25 msec) plus a single string of towed hydrophones (streamer) that determine geologic structure by detecting waves reflected by subsurface layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: >2000 Hz top-bandwidth single-channel seismic reflection systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Devices that provide information on unconsolidated sediment structure through transmission and reception of an energy source with a frequency corresponding to a sampling interval lower than 0.25 msec.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: >2000 Hz top-bandwidth sub-bottom penetrator and mud profiler systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: ADV is the acronym for acoustic doppler velocimeter. The group includes all in-situ instruments that make high frequency measurements of three-dimensional current velocity in order to determine the extent of turbulence within a water body.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: ADVs and turbulence probes

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that determine physical attributes such as size and abundance of atmospheric aerosols.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Aerosol physical characterisers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that quantify atmospheric particulate carbon ('black carbon') concentrations.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Aethalometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A marine seismic source where a propane-oxygen mixture is exploded inside a steel cylinder.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Aquapulse

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <mode>GPS localisation</mode><accuracy>better than 100m</accuracy>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Argos GPS-localised transmitters

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <mode>Doppler-derived Argos localisation</mode><accuracy>better than 250m (class 3) to worse than 1500m (class 0)</accuracy>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Argos doppler-localised transmitters

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <frequency>1.6-2MHz</frequency><mode>hyperbolic</mode><range>450km</range><accuracy>4-7m down to 20m at maximum range</accuracy><operational>from 1977 (mid-80s in Europe)</operational><notes>Survey positioning system.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Automatic Ranging Grid Overlay DM 54 receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A marine seismic energy source in which capacitors are charged to high voltage and then discharged through a transducer in the water. The transducer consists of a flat coil with a spring-loaded aluminium plate. Eddy currents force the plates to separate sharply, producing a low pressure region between the plates into which the water rushes generating a pressure wave by implosion.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Boomer

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A package lowered and raised vertically from a surface platform, usually a ship, always carrying pressure, temperature and conductivity sensors. Addional optional sensors include fluorometers, transmissometers and radiometers. The package may also carry water bottles.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: CTD

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A package towed at varying depths by a ship, always carrying pressure, temperature and conductivity sensors. Addional optional sensors include fluorometers, transmissometers and radiometers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: CTD undulators

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Chirp systems emit a 'swept-frequency signal', meaning that the transmitted signal is emitted over a period of time and over a set range of frequencies. This repeatable (transmitted) waveform can be varied in terms of pulse length, frequency bandwidth, and phase/amplitude. A matched filter, or correlation process, collapses the swept frequency modulated (FM) received signal into a pulse of short duration, maximizing the signal-to-noise-ratio. The reflected signal is received by a tuned transducer array that generates the outgoing acoustic energy. Chirps operate within a range of 400Hz - 24 kHz and are used for the first 20-30 metres of unconsolidated sediments.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Chirp

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <frequency>1.6MHz</frequency><mode>hyperbolic</mode><range>under 100km</range><accuracy>better than 10m: maximum accuracy at 50km range is 1.5m</accuracy><operating>1962 to 2000</operating><notes>Not for general navigation. Chains usually set up for specific surveys.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Decca Navigator System HiFix receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <frequency>70 and 130kHz</frequency><mode>hyperbolic</mode><range>450km (day) to 750km (night)</range><accuracy>50m(day) to 200m (night) in good conditions down to 2km near range limit</accuracy><operating>WWII to 2001-03 (2000-03-31 in UK)</operating><notes> Transmitter groups, each with a master and three slaves</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Decca Navigator System main chain receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <accuracy>better than 100m to better than 10m</accuracy><notes>GPS augmented by a network of fixed ground stations that continuously broadcast the difference between their true locations and the location determined from the satellites.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Differential Global Positioning System receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments primarily designed to detect shoals of fish through transmission and reception of acoustic signals. They are often optimised for this purpose through the use of multiple frequencies.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Fish-finder echosounders

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An implosive energy source for marine shooting. Two plates are separated by compressed air until they lock into position. The air between them is then pumped out creating a vacuum. On the signal the plates are unlocked and the water pressure forces them together creating a shock wave in the water.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Flexichoc

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A seismic method for marine shooting whereby small charges are propelled through a rubber hose by water under pressure into a steel cage where they are detonated. Holes in the cage allow the water repelled by the explosion to flow out and in thus dissipating some of the energy in the bubble effect
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Flexotir

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A marine seismic source where a pair of conventional airguns (one, the generator, fires in the conventional manner; the second, known as the injector) fires some milliseconds later to prevent bubble from collapsing. Could be used in true GI mode (volume of injector twice of volume of generator), harmonic mode (same volume of generator and injector) or true airgun (no delay between generator and injector).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: GI-gun

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <notes>Based on a network of satellites deployed by the former Soviet Union. The network was initiated in 1976 but fell into disrepair before full global coverage was reached during the political upheaval of the early 90s</notes>.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Global Navigation Satellite System receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <frequency>1.6-3.4MHz</frequency><mode>hyperbolic (usual), circular or combined</mode><range>250km (night) to 700km (day)</range><accuracy>up to 0.5-1m</accuracy><operating>until 2000</operating><notes>Racal positioning system similar to Decca HiFix based on temporary or permanent transmitter chains comprising a master plus at least two slaves.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Hyperfix receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <accuracy>Horizontal Accuracy: Fixed RTK mode: 1-5cm, Float RTK mode: 20cm-1m. Vertical accuracy : twice the horizontal accuracy</accuracy><operating>Since the mid-1990s</operating><notes>Real Time Kinematic (RTK) satellite navigation technique based on the use of carrier phase measurements of the GPS signals where a single reference station or a network of reference stations provides the real-time corrections.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Kinematic Global Positioning System receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <frequency>70-130kHz</frequency><mode>hyperbolic</mode><range>950kmto 1700km (day): 650km to 1250km (day)</range><operational>1947 to 2010. Maintained as GPS backup in the EU.</operational><notes>Global navigation based on transmitters in several European countries, Japan, Canada (until 2002-10) and USA (until 2010-02-08).</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Long Range Navigation version C receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <notes>Timepieces of sufficient precision to allow their use of portable time standards.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Marine chronometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <frequency>5410-5890MHz</frequency><range>up to 75km</range><accuracy>up to 2m</accuracy><notes>A family of short-wave receivers that determine position by determining the line-of-sight distance from 3 or more transmitters set up for the survey.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Motorola Mini-Ranger receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <accuracy>better than 100m</accuracy><notes>Global navigation based on a network of satellites deployed and maintained by the USA.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: NAVSTAR Global Positioning System receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <mode>Doppler-derived localisation</mode><accuracy>better than 10km or 2km if combined with relative water velocity em-log</accuracy>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Navy Navigation Satellite System receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <frequency>10-14kHz</frequency><mode>hyperbolic</mode><range>up to 15000km</range><accuracy>better than 7.4km</accuracy><operational>1968-1997</operational><notes>Global long-range but low accuracy navigation system</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Omega receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <frequency>100kHz</frequency><mode>hyperbolic</mode><range>250km to 750km</range><accuracy>30m to 500m</accuracy><operational>1970s to late 1990s</operational>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Pulse8 receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <frequency>around 300-400kHz</frequency><mode>hyperbolic</mode>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Rana receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <notes>Optical instruments that accurately measure the angle between pairs of visible celestial bodies such as the sun, moon or stars. </notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Sextants

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A seismic source in which an electrical discharge in water is the energy source
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Sparker

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <frequency>420-450MHz</frequency><mode>hyperbolic or circular</mode><range>400km hyperbolic; 75-100km circular</range><accuracy>better than 2m below horizon (10m above horizon)</accuracy><operational>1980s to 1995</operational><notes>Navigation and positioning system for the North Sea petroleum industry.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Système leger de measure de distance receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <frequency>around 2MHz</frequency><mode>hyperbolic</mode><range>150-200km</range><accuracy>better than 20m</accuracy><notes>Mostly used for aircraft.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Toran receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <frequency>420-450MHz</frequency><mode>circular</mode><range>150km</range><accuracy>better than 3m</accuracy><notes>Survey positioning system.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Trident receivers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <range>80km</range><accuracy>1m (resolution 0.1m)</accuracy><notes>Family of microwave short-range positioning systems with vessel equipment and three shore transponders (master and two slaves) set up specifically for surveys.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Trisponder navigation systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A marine seismic energy source in which a quantity of superheated steam under high pressure is iniected into water. Subsequent condensation of the steam attenuates bubble oscillation.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Vaporchoc

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that identify crystalline solids by measuring the characteristic spaces between layers of atoms or molecules in a crystal.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: X-ray diffractometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that identify and quantify the elemental constituents of a sample from the spectrum of electromagnetic radiation emitted by the atoms in the sample when excited by X-ray radiation.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: X-ray fluorescence analysers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments measuring the mass-to-charge ratio of the products of sample molecule disassociation, atom ionisation and ion acceleration in a particle accelerator.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: accelerator mass spectrometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure non-gravitational accelerations acting upon a spacecraft.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: accelerometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that measures the amount of sound energy transmitted into the water column returned to the instrument.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: acoustic backscatter sensors

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A network of acoustic sensors that determine the location of a sound source by triangulation such as acoustically active float tracking systems.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: acoustic tracking systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure the speed or velocity of sound, including P-waves, in samples of solids, liquids or gases
CodeDefinition.gml:name: acoustic velocity systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Apparatus where capture is based on chasing the target species (e.g. a trawl).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: active fishing gear

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Fluorometers that measure photosynthetic parameters by taking measurements whilst manipulating the phytoplankton with controlled high-intensity illumination such as pump and probe and FRRF
CodeDefinition.gml:name: active fluorometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device that collects a sample of aerosol (dry particles or liquid droplets) from the atmosphere
CodeDefinition.gml:name: aerosol samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A marine seismic source which injects a bubble of highly compressed air into the water. Oscillations of the bubble as it alternatively expands and contracts generate a sonic wave whose frequency depends on the amount of air in the bubble, its pressure, and the water depth.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: airgun

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A marine seismic source where multiple airguns of different sizes are tuned so that a broader frequency spectrum will be generated.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: airgun array

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure their distance above a specified elevation such as the sea surface or the seabed. Classification includes acoustic and pressure-based instruments that are designed to provide platform z co-ordinate spatial coverage in the atmosphere or a water body. It excludes remote sensing instruments such as LIDAR and satellite radar altimeters designed to map surface elevation.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: altimiters

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that measures wind speed and direction at a single elevation
CodeDefinition.gml:name: anemometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: In-situ instruments that can determine the proportion of one or more gaseous components of the atmosphere.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: atmospheric gas analysers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Sensors that measure the intensity an nature of electromagnetic radiation in a manner optimised for the quantification of atmospheric phenomena.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: atmospheric radiometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that volatilise the sample, illuminate the resultant vapour with light wavelengths matched to the analyte of interest and quantify the radiation absorbed, which is proportional to concentration.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: atomic absorption spectrometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that continuously draw samples through plumbing adding reagents whilst controlling the environment to produce a chemical reaction before passing the sample to a detector, e.g. the automated colorimetric determination of nutrients.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: autoanalysers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Devices that determine the mass or weight of a sample.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: balances and scales

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure the depth of a water body by determining the distances from the platform to the surface and the bed by timing reflected pulses of laser light.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: bathymetric LiDARs

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure vertical profiles of sea temperature by either lowering a pressure plus temperature senor package (MBT) or dropping a free falling disposable sensor (XBT).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: bathythermographs

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Nets towed over the sea floor having the horizontal net opening provided by a wooden or metal beam that disrupts the surface of the bed.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: beam trawls

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that determinesthe amount of chlorophyll in in-vitro samples by measuring the quantity of red light (around 685nm) emitted following excitation by pulses of blue light (around 460-470nm).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: bench fluorometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device that isolates a portion of seabed plus overlying water from its surroundings. Either returns the entire system to the surface or incorporates sampling devices and/or in-situ sensors.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: benthic incubation chambers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A net or sledge dragged across the seabed designed to sample benthic fauna.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: benthos samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: X-band and S-band radar systems developed for the detection, tracking and counting of birds in flight
CodeDefinition.gml:name: bird detection radars

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure the concentration and size of air bubbles in the water column.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: bubble detectors

CodeDefinition.gml:description: All types of photographic equipment that may be deployed in aircraft or satellites including stills, video, film and digital systems.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: cameras

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Devices that separate the liquid and solid phases of a sample through forces exerted by rapid rotation
CodeDefinition.gml:name: centrifuges

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments measuring the amount of light of a given wavelength absorbed by a sample of solution to determine the concentration of a specific coloured solute.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: colorimeters

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device that continuously supplies a flow of air either to an analytical instrument, over a sensor or from which discrete samples may be drawn
CodeDefinition.gml:name: continuous air samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device that continuously supplies a flow of water either to an analytical instrument, over a sensor or from which samples may be drawn
CodeDefinition.gml:name: continuous water samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Systems that measure sub-surface resistivity structure through the measurement of the electromegnetic fields resulting from stimulation by a towed source. Includes systems incorporating both transmitter and receiver and systems where the transmitter and receiver are separate.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: controlled-source elecromagnetic systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that measures current speed and direction at a single depth
CodeDefinition.gml:name: current meters

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that measures current speed and direction at multiple predetermined depths simultaneously
CodeDefinition.gml:name: current profilers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <notes>The process of estimating current position based upon a previously determined position, or fix, and advancing that position based upon known or estimated speeds over elapsed time, and course.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: dead reckoning

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Nets towed over the sea floor designed to sample species living on or near the bottom.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: demersal trawl nets

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device that collects a sample of air from the atmosphere and stores it, usually under pressure, for subsequent analysis
CodeDefinition.gml:name: discrete air samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device that collects an in-situ discrete water sample from any depth and returns it to the surface without contamination by the waters through which it passes, such as a water bottle
CodeDefinition.gml:name: discrete water samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that measures the concentration of gases, generally oxygen, dissolved in the water column
CodeDefinition.gml:name: dissolved gas sensors

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A sudden release of stress in the Earth's crust that creates energy in the form of seimic waves.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: earthquake

CodeDefinition.gml:description: In-situ sensors that simultaneuously measure electrical and magnetic fields. They are usually moored on the seabed for long periods of time for determination of deep structure through monitoring magnetotelluric currents. However, some may also be configured to be receivers for active electromagnetic surveys such as CSEM.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: elecromagnetic sensors

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that chemically analyse a small area of a sample by bombarding it with electrons and spectroscopically assaying the resulting X-Ray emissions.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: electron microprobes

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that generate enlarged images of samples using the phenomena of reflection and absorption of electrons behaving as waves.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: electron microscopes

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that quantify carbon, nitrogen and sometimes other elements by combusting the sample at very high temperature and assaying the resulting gaseous oxides. Usually used for samples including organic material.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: elemental analysers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure vertical profiles of sea temperature and salinity with a free falling disposable temperature and conductivity sensor package.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: expendable CTDs

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Sensors that quantify the rate at which fluids (e.g. water or air) pass through sensor packages, instruments or sampling devices.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: flow meters

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that generate enlarged images of samples using the phenomena of fluorescence and phosphorescence instead of, or in addition to, reflection and absorption of visible light. Includes conventional and inverted instruments.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: fluorescence microscopes

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that measures the amount of stimulated electromagnetic radiation produced by pulses of electromagnetic radiation emitted into the water column
CodeDefinition.gml:name: fluorometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Devices primarily designed to drill wells through sediment or rock that flush the drill spoil back to the surface where it is examined to provide lithological data through the process known as mud logging.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: flushing drills

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device that condenses a sample of fog from the atmosphere
CodeDefinition.gml:name: fog samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments measuring the relative levels of electromagnetic radiation of different wavelengths in the gamma-ray waveband.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: gamma-ray spectrometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments separating gases, volatile substances or substances dissolved in a volatile solvent by transporting an inert gas through a column packed with a sorbent to a detector for assay by a mass spectrometer.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: gas chromatograph mass spectrometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments separating gases, volatile substances or substances dissolved in a volatile solvent by transporting an inert gas through a column packed with a sorbent to a detector for assay.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: gas chromatographs

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that separate components in aqueous or organic solution based on molecular size generally for molecular weight determination.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: gel permeation chromatographs

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments carrying a sensor that determines the temperature (degree of hotness) within geological units.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: geothermometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Nets drifting in the sea or standing on the sea floor in which fish become entangled, usually through their gill covers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: gill nets

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that makes measurements of the Earth's gravity field
CodeDefinition.gml:name: gravimeters

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Groups all explosives that allows high penetration but low resolution surveys
CodeDefinition.gml:name: high penetration low resolution explosives

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that separate and analyse mixtures of substances by high pressure pumping the sample through a column packed with microspheres coated with the stationary phase.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: high performance liquid chromatographs

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Groups all explosives that allows high resolution but low penetration surveys
CodeDefinition.gml:name: high resolution low penetration explosives

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A fine-meshed net or filter towed behind a moving vessel that collects a single sample for a tow. Samples microzooplankton, mesozooplankton and nekton.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: high-speed plankton samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Devices containing transducers that convert underwater sound waves into electrical signals.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: hydrophones

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A rig that allows water samples to be retained from where they were collected whilst physically separated from their surroundings. Includes small-scale incubation rigs and mesocosms.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: in-situ incubators

CodeDefinition.gml:description: There is no appropriate value. To be used in cases where metadata elements cannot be set null due to schema constraints.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: inapplicable

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that pass nebulised samples into an inductively-coupled gas plasma (8-10000 K) where they are atomised and excited. The de-excitation optical emissions at characteristic wavelengths are spectroscopically analysed.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: inductively-coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopes

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that pass nebulised samples into an inductively-coupled gas plasma (8-10000 K) where they are atomised and ionised. Ions of specific mass-to-charge ratios are quantified in a quadrupole mass spectrometer.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <notes>Systems that determine spatial position using high-accuracy inertial measurements plus input from other sensors such as doppler current sensors to determine platform 3-D location by interpolation between satellite network fixes.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: inertial navigation systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that locate acoustic reflectors such as fronts in the water column by transmitting pulses of sound from the seabed and determing reflection return times
CodeDefinition.gml:name: inverted echosounders

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that isotopically analyse a small area of sample by bombarding it with ions to form a plasma that is analysed in a mass spectrometer.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: ion microprobes

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that determine the distance between the platform and the Earth's surface by timing reflected pulses of laser light.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: laser altimiters

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments assaying beta radiation by quantitative detection of visible light produced by the passage of rays or particles through a suitable scintillant incorporated into the sample.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: liquid scintillation counters

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An acoustic doppler current meter lowered and raised vertically from a surface platform, typically a ship.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: lowered current profilers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Sensors, probes and meters that measure the degree to which a sample or part thereof is influenced by a magnetic field
CodeDefinition.gml:name: magnetic susceptibility systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that makes measurements of the Earth's magnetic field
CodeDefinition.gml:name: magnetometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A simple tool like a hammer, saw or even just a hand for the collection of biota samples
CodeDefinition.gml:name: manual biota samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A simple tool like a hammer, saw or even just a hand for the collection of rock samples
CodeDefinition.gml:name: manual rock samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A marine seismic source generating sweeps of controlled varying frequency (from a few Hz to hundreds of Hz) and duration.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: marine vibroseis

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments used to measure the mass-to-charge ratio of ions most generally used to find the composition of a sample by generating a mass spectrum representing the masses of sample components.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: mass spectrometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: In-situ instruments that can determine the total, dissolved or particulate concentration of one or more metallic elements (including trace metalloids like arsenic) in a water body.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: metal analysers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that makes routine meteorological measurements on the atmosphere, typically air pressure, temperature and humidity
CodeDefinition.gml:name: meteorological packages

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Fast response sensors sampled at high frequency to determine the distribution of water body properties on a millimetric scale.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: microstructure sensors

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure water depth along several tracks parallel to the platform track by timing pulses of sound reflected on the seafloor
CodeDefinition.gml:name: multi-beam echosounders

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An energy source of unspecified frequency plus a multiple strings of towed hydrophones (streamers) that determine geologic structure by detecting waves reflected by subsurface layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: multi-channel seismic reflection systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A system comprising several nets that can be opened and closed sequentially to collect a series of samples during a tow or haul. Samples microzooplankton, mesozooplankton and nekton.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: multinet

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Any kind of natural source of acoustic waves, that can be used in passive seismics
CodeDefinition.gml:name: natural source

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A fine-meshed net designed to collect samples living within a few centimetres of the sea surface. Samples microzooplankton, mesozooplankton and nekton.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: neuston net

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that identify and quantify magnetically active chemical entities by subjecting a sample to orthogonal magnetic and electrical fields.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that makes in-situ measurements of one or more of nitrate, nitrite, ammonium, urea, phosphate or silicate dissolved in the water column
CodeDefinition.gml:name: nutrient analysers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Humans who estimate a parameter through observation of a phenomenon such as bird counts and visual wave observations
CodeDefinition.gml:name: observers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Sensors that measure the intensity and nature of electromagnetic radiation in a manner optimised for the determination of ocean chlorophyll concentration.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: ocean colour radiometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that measures the amount of electromagnetic radiation emitted into the water column returned to the instrument.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: optical backscatter sensors

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that generate enlarged images of samples using the phenomena of reflection and absorption of visible light. Includes conventional and inverted instruments.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: optical microscopes

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure the hydrogen ion concentration in the water column
CodeDefinition.gml:name: pH sensors

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure the size spectrum of particulate material suspended in a water sample.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: particle sizers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An instrument that measures the size spectrum of particles suspended in the water column
CodeDefinition.gml:name: particle sizers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A system that collects samples of water column particulates such as in-situ high volume filtration systems liks SAPs.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: particulates samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Apparatus where capture is based on the movement of the target species towards the gear (e.g. creels and fish traps).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: passive fishing gear

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A net towed through the water column designed to sample free-swimming nekton or fish.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: pelagic trawl nets

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Dynamic or passive devices that determine the consistency or hardness of soil or sediment by measuring the depth or rate of penetration of a needle or cone rig into it when a known force is applied.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: penetrometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Devices that measure fluid (air, gas, water, or oil) pressure within soil, sediment, rock or concrete providing information such as water table level in an aquifer system.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: piezometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that categorise and count plankton in the water column
CodeDefinition.gml:name: plankton counters

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A fine-meshed net designed for sampling microzooplankton, mesozooplankton or nekton.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: plankton nets

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device that continuously samples a flow of water, separating and fixing plankton for subsequent identification and counting
CodeDefinition.gml:name: plankton recorders

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure platform orientation or rates of platform motion or acceleration in any direction or along any axis. Excludes inertial navigation systems that are designed to determine platform location with respect to an external co-ordinate reference system.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: platform attitude sensors

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Devices comprising a weight attached to the end of a graduated rope used to measure point water depths.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: plummets

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure either the rate of fall or integrated amount of rain, snow, sleet, hail or graupel.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: precipitation gauges

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device that collects a sample of precipitation (rain, hail or snow) as it falls
CodeDefinition.gml:name: precipitation samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that determine the distance between the platform and the Earth's surface by timing reflected electromagnetic radiation, usually microwaves.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: radar altimeters

CodeDefinition.gml:description: <notes>Directional radio receivers that determine the location of a mobile radio transmitter (such as a bird or animal tag) by triangulation.</notes>
CodeDefinition.gml:name: radio tracking systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that measures the intensity of electromagnetic radiation in either the atmosphere or the water column
CodeDefinition.gml:name: radiometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A balloon-borne package equipped with a radio transmitter and meteorological sensors typically measuring temperature, pressure, and humidity.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: radiosondes

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure the tendency of the water column to either gain or lose electrons when it is subject to change by introduction of a new species
CodeDefinition.gml:name: redox potential sensors

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device that drills into rock extracting a cylindrical sample
CodeDefinition.gml:name: rock corers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device dragged across the seabed designed to collect loose rock samples.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: rock dredges

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Devices that allow one or more physical dimensions of a sample or specimen to be determined by visible comparison against marked graduations in units of measurement of dimension length.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: rulers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that simultaneously measures electrical conductivity and temperature in the water column to provide temperature and salinity data
CodeDefinition.gml:name: salinity sensor

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure the salinity of a collected water sample by comparing its electrical conductivity with that of a standard sea water solution.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: salinometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Devices that label the region within which sampling is to be confined such as permanent quadrants and location markers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: sampling extent markers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A network of statellites that generate signals that allow a receiver to determine its position such as GPS.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: satellite positioning systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A network of statellites that determines the position of a transponder by triangulation such as Argos. Generally used to track surface buoys for the determination of Lagrangian currents.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: satellite tracking system

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Sensors that measure the reflection or scattering effect produced while scanning the surface of the earth. Primarily used to measure near surface winds over the oceans.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: scatterometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that make smoothed measuremeants of the elevation of the sea surface relative to a fixed vertical datum
CodeDefinition.gml:name: sea level recorders

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Bucket-like containers hauled over the sea bed collecting integrated samples of surface sediment along a segment of ship track.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: sediment dredges

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device that collects a sample of surface sediment including manually deployed equipment like a shovel or bucket.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: sediment grabs

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device that collects samples of pore water from various horizons below the seabed.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: sediment porewater samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Devices that provide in-situ still or video images of a section including bottom water, the undisturbed sediment-water interface and the upper sediment layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: sediment profile imagers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A specialised water bottle that both collects water samples and provides a settling velocity experiment apparatus.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: sediment settling tubes

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Physical markers that allow changes in the position of the boundary between sediment and air or water by visible comparison against marked graduations in units of measurement of dimension length.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: sediment surface markers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A collector of particulates as they sink through the water column
CodeDefinition.gml:name: sediment traps

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A network of seismometers or geophones plus an energy source that determine geologic structure by detecting waves refracted by subsurface layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: seismic refraction systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Devices placed on the ground or seabed to measure physical movement of that substrate.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: seismometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device mounted on a ship that holds water samples under conditions of controlled temperature or controlled temperature and illumination.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: shipboard incubators

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments with directional acoustic transmitters and receivers fitted to an underwater platform that emit fan-shaped pulses down toward the seafloor across a wide angle perpendicular to the path of the platform through the water.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: sidescan sonars

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Devices that separate solid particles larger than a particular size from a sample collected by another device that is a suspension of solid particles in a liquid or gas
CodeDefinition.gml:name: sieves and filters

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure water depth at a single point below the platform by timing pulses of sound reflected on the seafloor
CodeDefinition.gml:name: single-beam echosounders

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Array of air gun tuned in order to obtain the necessary energy wile reducing the size of the air guns
CodeDefinition.gml:name: single-bubble airgun

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An energy source of unspecified frequency plus a single string of towed hydrophones (streamer) that determine geologic structure by detecting waves reflected by subsurface layers.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: single-channel seismic reflection systems

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A device that collects a sample of frozen seawater or accumulated frozen precipitation
CodeDefinition.gml:name: snow and ice samplers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that measures the velocity of sound in seawater
CodeDefinition.gml:name: sound velocity sensors

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments measuring the relative absorption of electromagnetic radiation of different wavelengths in the near infra-red, visible and ultraviolet wavebands by samples.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: spectrophotometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Electrical conductors routed beneath the sea and connecting land stations. Oceanographic interest focuses on changes in electrical resistance that may be related to the magnitude of Lagrangian currents.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: submarine cables

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that measure the speed and direction of sea surface travel by timing reflected radio waves
CodeDefinition.gml:name: surface current radars

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that generate maps of radar reflectivity through the synthesis of multiple pulses from a moving platform.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: synthetic aperture radars

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Sensors that measure the intensity and nature of electromagnetic radiation in a manner optimised for the quantification of terrestrial phenomena.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: terrestrial radiometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Laboratory instruments that determine the thermal conductivity of rock or sediment samples (including unopened cores).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: thermal conductivimeters

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A group of rigidly-mounted temperature sensors sampled by a common data logger held at various depths in the water column.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: thermistor chains

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Temperature and conductivity sensors mounted on a sea-surface platform continuously measuring a surface water supply.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: thermosalinographs

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instruments that incrementally add quantified aliquites of a reagent to a sample until the end-point of a chemical reaction is reached.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: titrators

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Systems that measure the attenuation of electromagnetic radiation by the water column. Includes human observer plus Secchi Disk.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: transmissometers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Devices designed to collect samples of unconsolidated sediment from between the surface and depths from a metre to 10s of metres with minimal disturbance of the sediment structure.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: unconsolidated sediment corers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: All types of photographic equipment that may be deployed underwater including stills, video, film and digital systems
CodeDefinition.gml:name: underwater cameras

CodeDefinition.gml:description: The correct value is not known to and not computable by the creator of this information. However a correct value probably exists.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: unknown

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Sensors that measure the intensity and nature of electromagnetic radiation emitted from the Earth in a manner optimised for the determination of water body surface temperature.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: water body temperature sensor

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Fixed physical markers that allow changes in the position of the boundary between a water body and the atmosphere by visible comparison against marked graduations in units of measurement of dimension length.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: water level markers

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An instrument that measures the temperature of the water with which it is in contact
CodeDefinition.gml:name: water temperature sensor

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A marine seismic energy source divided into two chambers, the firing chamber, which contains compressed air, and the other chamber, which is filled with water. When the gun is fired, the compressed air forces the shuttle downward and this expels the water from the lower chamber. The shot of water leaving the gun creates a void behind it and the collapse of water into this void creates an acoustic wave.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: watergun

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Instrument that measures water column surface wave parameters including height, period, direction and energy spectra.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: wave recorders

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A six-wheel drive amphibious truck developed during the second World War.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: DUKW

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A fixed-wing self-propelled aircraft.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: aeroplane

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A self-propelled container filled with a gas that is lighter than air.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: airship

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A self-propelled vehicle capable of operation on land or the seabed (e.g. beach crawler)
CodeDefinition.gml:name: amphibious crawler

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A self-propelled platform capable of operating on land and within or on the surface of a water body.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: amphibious vehicle

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An aircraft without wings that obtains its lift from the rotation of overhead blades, but obtains forward populsion from a fixed propellor.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: autogyro

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A self-propelled vehicle operating on the sea surface with no human occupants.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: autonomous surface water vehicle

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A free-roving platform operating in the water column with propulsion but no human operator on board (e.g. Autosub, Glider).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: autonomous underwater vehicle

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A structure to which instrumentation may be attached that is either in air or under water depending on the state of the tide and weather conditions.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: beach/intertidal zone structure

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform capable of flight in the atmosphere because it is lighter than air.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: buoyant aircraft

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A mammal that exists within the water column but needing to regularly surface to breathe (i.e. dolphins and whales).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: cetacean

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A fixed man-made structure permanently linked to land with access to water at all states of the tide to which instrumentation may be attached (e.g. pier)
CodeDefinition.gml:name: coastal structure

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A frozen body of water on land, freshwater or sea.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: cryosphere

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A human being with self-contained equipment or surface-connected suit enabling operation within the water column.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: diver

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform operating in the water column attached to a mothership by an umbilical but with no means of propulsion that has at least one human operator on board (e.g. bathysphere).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: drifting manned submersible

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An unmanned instrumented platform drifting freely in the water column at a depth governed by its density (e.g. Swallow float)
CodeDefinition.gml:name: drifting subsurface float

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An unmanned instrumented platform drifting freely in the water column that periodically makes vertical traverses through the water column (e.g. Argo float)
CodeDefinition.gml:name: drifting subsurface profiling float

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An unmanned instrumented platform operating on the surface of the water column often attached to a drogue to track currents rather than winds (e.g. Argos buoy).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: drifting surface float

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A free-swimming creature that exists totally within the water column.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: fish

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform operating on the surface of the water column whose primary purpose is the commercial harevsting of fish or shellfish but may be engaged in scientific activities such as fish stock surveys or mooring deployments and recoveries.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: fishing vessel

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A collection of oceanographic instruments mounted at a fixed position on the seabed (e.g. POL Monitoring Platform, seabed ADCP)
CodeDefinition.gml:name: fixed benthic node

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform that periodically makes an automated vertical traverse of the water column at a predetermined fixed location. (e.g. YSI vertical profiler, HOMER CTD)
CodeDefinition.gml:name: fixed subsurface vertical profiler

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A bird that is unable to fly with the ability to exist within the water column (e.g. penguin).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: flightless bird

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A free-floating platform either on the surface of the water column or at a predetermined depth within the water column.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: float

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A container filled with a gas that is lighter than air, which is free to drift in the atmosphere.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: free-floating balloon

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A container filled with a gas that is lighter than air, which is constrained to rise vertically at a fixed location.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: free-rising balloon

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A vehicle operating beyond the Earth's atmosphere without human occupants that orbits the Earth at the same rate as the Earth's rotation keeping it over a fixed location on the Earth's surface..
CodeDefinition.gml:name: geostationary orbiting satellite

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A fixed-wing aircraft with no propulsion.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: glider

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An aircraft without wings that obtains its lift from the rotation of overhead blades.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: helicopter

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A craft capable of moving over water or land on a downwardly-propelled cushion of air.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: hovercraft

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A human being without specialised equipment operating on land or the surface of the water column.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: human

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A floating ice sheet detached from the coast.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: ice island

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A floating ice sheet attached to the coast.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: ice shelf

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An aerofoil tethered to the ground held aloft by the wind.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: kite

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform located on the solid surface of the Earth either above or below sea level.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: land or seafloor

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A mammal that exists both on land and within the water column. Includes seals, sealions, sea-otters and walruses.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: land-sea mammals

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A fixed man-made structure on land to which instrumentation may be attached (e.g. meteorolgical tower)
CodeDefinition.gml:name: land/onshore structure

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An instrumented land vehicle (e.g. mobile meteorological station, land crawler)
CodeDefinition.gml:name: land/onshore vehicle

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An unmanned platform lowered and raised vertically by a cable from the mothership. Includes any type of profiling sensor mounting such as CTD frames, profiling radiometers and instrumented nets.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: lowered unmanned submersible

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform operating on the surface of the water column that is manually propelled and may not be easily removed from the water (e.g. trireme).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: man-powered boat

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform operating on the surface of the water column that is manually propelled and may be easily removed from the water (e.g. rowing boat, canoe).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: man-powered small boat

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A vehicle operating beyond the Earth's atmosphere with human occupants.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: manned spacecraft

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A large polythene bag containing a water sample suspended in the natural environment so that it shares ambient physical conditions such as temperature and light levels, but is chemically isolated to allow experiments such as fertilisation.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: mesocosm bag

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An unmanned instrumented platform operating on the surface of the water column loosely tethered to the seafloor to maintain a fixed position (e.g. ODAS buoy)
CodeDefinition.gml:name: moored surface buoy

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A tethered collection of oceanographic instruments at a fixed location that may include seafloor, mid-water and surface components.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: mooring

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform operating on the surface of the water column in unpredictable locations that is primarily equipped, manned and operated for military purposes. Includes surface warships of all sizes and logistic support vessels.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: naval vessel

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform capable of flight in the atmosphere despite its being heavier than air.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: non-buoyant aircraft

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A fixed (for the duration of the measurements) man-made structure away from the coast to which instrumentation may be attached (e.g. oil rig, gas rig or jack-up barge)
CodeDefinition.gml:name: offshore structure

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A vehicle operating beyond the Earth's atmosphere without human occupants that orbits the Earth at a different rate to the Earth's rotation so it moves over the Earth's surface..
CodeDefinition.gml:name: orbiting satellite

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A living creature carrying instruments or collecting samples
CodeDefinition.gml:name: organism

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A fabric sheet designed to slow the descent of an object through the atmosphere.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: parachute

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform operating in the water column that has both self-contained propulsion and at least one human operator on board (e.g. submarine)
CodeDefinition.gml:name: propelled manned submersible

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform operating in the water column attached to a mothership by an umbilical with limited propulsion and no human operator on board (e.g. ROV).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: propelled unmanned submersible

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A fixed-wing self-propelled aircraft that is equipped, manned and operated for atmospheric, meteorological or oceanographic research.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: research aeroplane

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform of any size operating on the surface of the water column in unpredictable locations that is specifically equipped, manned and operated for scientific, usually oceanographic, research.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: research vessel

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An instrumented structure in a river upstream of its tidal limit.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: river station

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A rocket is a vehicle, missile or aircraft which obtains thrust by the reaction to the ejection of fast moving exhaust gas from within a rocket engine.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: rocket

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A vehicle operating beyond the Earth's atmosphere without human occupants that orbits the Earth.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: satellite

CodeDefinition.gml:description: An instrumented platform that is propelled on wheels or tracks on the seabed (e.g benthic crawler).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: sea bed vehicle

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A flighted bird that is able to exist on the water column surface and dive into the water column (e.g. cormorants, auks, ducks and gulls).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: seabird and duck

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A small self-propelled platform operating on the surface of the water column in unpredictable locations that is smaller than a ship, but too large to easily remove from the water.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: self-propelled boat

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A small self-propelled platform operating on the surface of the water column that may be easily removed from the water (e.g. shore-based RIBs, ships' boats).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: self-propelled small boat

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A large platform operating on the surface of the water column. Objective definitions for guidelines: >50m length (EU), >100 foot length (USA), >300 GRT weight (SOLAS). Subjective definition: a ship is a vessel big enough to carry a boat.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: ship

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform operating beyond the Earth's atmosphere
CodeDefinition.gml:name: spacecraft

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform operating within a water body.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: submersible

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A collection of oceanographic instruments attached to wires suspended between anchors on the seabed and buoyant spheres in the water column.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: subsurface mooring

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A mobile platform with propulsion operating on and restricted to the surface of a water body.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: surface vessel

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A container filled with a gas that is lighter than air, which is tethered at a fixed height and location.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: tethered balloon

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A vehicle towed by rigid cable through the water column at fixed or varying depth with no propulsion and no human operator (e.g. Towfish, Scanfish, UOR, SeaSoar)
CodeDefinition.gml:name: towed unmanned submersible

CodeDefinition.gml:description: The correct value is not known to, and not computable by, the creator of this information. However, a correct value probably exists.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: unknown

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform of any size occupying a fixed location on the surface of the water column for prolonged periods collecting scientific (oceanographic and meteorological) data as a primary or secondary mission. Includes light vessels and weather ships.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: vessel at fixed position

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform for purpose of commerce of any size operating on the surface of the water column in unpredictable locations that regularly collects scientific (oceanographic and meteorological) data (e.g. an instrumented cargo vessel).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: vessel of opportunity

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A platform repeatedly following a predictable fixed track on the surface of the water column that collects scientific (oceanographic and meteorological) data (e.g. an instrumented ferry).
CodeDefinition.gml:name: vessel of opportunity on fixed route

CodeListDictionary.gml:description: Co-ordinate reference systems used for positions (latitude/longitude or grid references) in SeaDataNet metadata. May include 3D co-ordinate systems, but not vertical elevation datums like OD Newlyn.

CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 72BE

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - geographic 2D - used in the area of: World with the scope: Horizontal component of 3D system.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 72BE

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 30 to 24 deg W with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 72BE / UTM zone 26N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 12 to 6 deg W with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 72BE / UTM zone 29N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 6 to 0 deg W with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.

CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 72BE / UTM zone 31N

CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 72BE / UTM zone 32N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 24 to 30 deg E with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 72BE / UTM zone 35N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 30 to 36 deg E with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 72BE / UTM zone 36N

CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 72BE / UTM zone 37N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 42 to 48 deg E with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 72BE / UTM zone 38N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 48 to 54 deg E with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 72BE / UTM zone 39N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - geographic 2D - used in the area of: World with the scope: Horizontal component of 3D system. Used by the GPS satellite navigation system and for NATO military geodetic surveying.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World with the scope: Graticule coordinates expressed in simple Cartesian form.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / Plate Carree

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N of 60 deg N with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UPS North

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - between 0 and 84 deg N with the scope: For strict use within zone boundaries
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM grid system (northern hemisphere)

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 30 to 24 deg W - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 26N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 24 to 18 deg W - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 27N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 18 to 12 deg W - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 28N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 12 to 6 deg W - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 29N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 6 to 0 deg W - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 30N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 0 to 6 deg E - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 31N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 6 to 12 deg E - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 32N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 12 to 18 deg E - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 33N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 18 to 24 deg E - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 34N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 24 to 30 deg E - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 35N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 30 to 36 deg E - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 36N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 36 to 42 deg E - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 37N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 42 to 48 deg E - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 38N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - N hemisphere - 48 to 54 deg E - by country with the scope: Large and medium scale topographic mapping and engineering survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / UTM zone 39N

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: World - between 80 deg S and 84 deg N with the scope: Very small scale mapping.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: World Geodetic System 84 / World Mercator

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - geographic 2D - used in the area of: Faroe Islands - onshore with the scope: Cadastre.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: fk89

CodeDefinition.gml:description: A coordinate reference system of type - projected - used in the area of: Faroe Islands - onshore with the scope: Cadastral survey.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: fk89 / Faroe Lambert FK89

CodeDefinition.gml:description: The correct value is not known to and not computable by the creator of this information. However a correct value probably exists.
CodeDefinition.gml:name: unknown

CodeListDictionary.gml:description: Types of metadata record in the SeaDataNet metadata

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Metadata record providing discovery and evaluation metadata for a SeaDataNet data object
CodeDefinition.gml:name: Common Data Index record

CodeDefinition.gml:description: Metadata record providing discovery metadata for a product such as a DTM which is provided by a data provider in place of their actual survey data as source for the project.
